lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
Generics allow us to write flexible, reusable code that can work with any data type while maintaining type safety.

They allow us to create code that can work with various types without sacrificing the benefits of strong typing.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
To show you the benefit of generics, let's look at a simple function that finds the biggest number in an array.

Make sure to pick function, followed by findMaxNumber, and finally findMaxNumber.

lessons.title: Lesson #14 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to do the same with strings where we look for the maximum value alphabetically, we could define another function.

Make sure to pick function, followed by findMaxString, and finally findMaxString.

lessons.title: Lesson #14 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Instead of defining the function twice, we can use generics to allow any type later. For now, we use T as a placeholder for any type.

Make sure to pick T, followed by T, and finally T.

First, we have to indicate that we will use a generic type. We do that with sharp brackets around a generic letter like T.

Make sure to pick <, followed by T, and finally >.

lessons.title: 123 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
After declaring the generic type, we can call it with any type.

Make sure to pick < followed by number and then >, [1, 3, 2].

lessons.title: 123 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to use a different type for the generic, we can specify that.

Make sure to pick < followed by string and then >, ["a", "b", "c"].

lessons.title: 123 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
As TypeScript is pretty good when it comes to inferring types, we can omit the generic type declaration inside the sharp brackets.

Call the function without explicitly specifying the generic type.

Make sure to pick findMax, followed by findMax.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also use generics when creating a class. We define the generic class with <T> that we then can use throughout the class.

Make sure to pick <, followed by T, and finally >.

lessons.title: Lesson #9 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
After defining the generic class T, we can now use it as the type of the variable value.

Make sure to pick T, followed by T.

lessons.title: Lesson #9 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If our class uses a generic type, we can use it with any type we want. We add the type we want inside the sharp brackets.

Make sure to pick new, followed by Container<number>.

lessons.title: Lesson #9 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use Container to also create a container with the type string.

Make sure to pick new followed by Container and then <, string, >.

lessons.title: Lesson #9 - Copy -
lessons.interactiveContent:
However, once we define a Container instance with a specific type, such as a number, we cannot assign a value of a different type to it.

Try assigning a string value to see the error.

Make sure to pick "Let me in!".

lessons.title: Lesson #9 - Copy -  - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Last but not least, we can leave the type specification for the generic out as TypeScript can infer it.

Make sure to pick new Container.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
What do we mean by <T> in the declaration of generic in TypeScript?

It is a placeholder for any typeIt is a specific type

It is a placeholder for any type.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code using generics.

Make sure to pick T, followed by T, and finally T.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the benefit of using generics in TypeScript?

It makes the code more reusableIt reduces the flexibility of the code

It makes the code more reusable.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
Ensure the repeat function works with any type by using a generic type.

Make sure to pick < followed by T and then >, T, T, T.

lessons.title: move - 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's revisit arrays with our newly gained knowledge of generics. As you see, there are two ways to define an array in TypeScript.

Make sure to pick Array, followed by <number>.

lessons.title: move - 1 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
An array is a collection of elements stored in a single variable. This collection Array<T> uses a generic type.

Make sure to pick Array followed by < and then number, >.

lessons.title: move - 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
As you know, we can also define an array of strings. This also works with the generic way of defining array types.

Make sure to pick Array followed by < and then string, >.

lessons.title: move -3
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also create interfaces with a generic type. The initial syntax looks similar to classes with generics that we've seen before.

Make sure to pick < followed by T and then >, T, <, T, >, T.

lessons.title: move -3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Creating a variable of type BoxClass and one that implements the interface BoxInterface looks similar as well.

Make sure to pick < followed by string and then >, <, string, >.

lessons.title: move -3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also omit adding the type explicitly for the BoxClass class as TypeScript will be able to infer it.

Make sure to pick =, followed by new, and finally BoxClass.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now, let's look at functions. Here's a simple function named getId that returns the id of an object.

Make sure to pick object.id.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can replace the any type with T, which allows our function to take any data type.

Make sure to pick T, followed by T, and finally T.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want our return type to always be a specific type, we can define that, too.

Make sure to pick string, followed by toString().

lessons.title: move - 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
How will you declare an array of numbers in TypeScript generics?

let numbers: Array<number> = [1, 2, 3];let numbers: Array = [1, 2, 3];

let numbers: Array<number> = [1, 2, 3];.

lessons.title: move -5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's create an interface with generics.

Make sure to type <T>.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a class called GenericClass using generics.

Make sure to pick GenericClass <T>.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
How does the definition of the GenericClass interface look?

interface GenericClass<T> { ... }interface GenericClass { ... }

interface GenericClass<T> { ... }.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Call the identity function using the correct type.

Make sure to pick identity, followed by <number>.
